SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described.
Content: Which phrase describes the main purpose of paragraphs 1 and 2?

A.Choice: To give details about the place where the story happens

B.Choice: To provide background information for the story

C.Choice: To tell when the events in the story happen

D.Choice: To reveal the causes of the events in the story

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence states an important theme of the story?

A.Choice: Brothers should be nice to their sisters.

B.Choice: Nature is more powerful than humans.

C.Choice: Humans are capable of extraordinary actions.

D.Choice: Family members should spend time together.

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described.
Content: Which sentence gives information about Yang Ki's brother that would be missing if the story had been told from her point of view?

A.Choice: “I am so angry that I think of throwing a stone at her.” (paragraph 9)

B.Choice: “I shrug my shoulders and start running again.” (paragraph 13)

C.Choice: “I fall headlong toward the edge of the canyon.” (paragraph 15)

D.Choice: “I wrap my arm around the trunk and pull myself to safety.” (paragraph 28)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 27.
:box:Her thin arms are like steel bands holding the pole in place.
The author uses the phrase “like steel bands” most likely to

A.Choice: reveal Yang Ki's calmness.

B.Choice: describe Yang Ki's appearance.

C.Choice: emphasize Yang Ki's strength.

D.Choice: explain Yang Ki's position.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 13.
:box:If Yang Ki loses sight of me, she may become discouraged and turn back.
Which phrase means the same as d͟i͟s͟c͟o͟u͟r͟a͟g͟e͟d?

A.Choice: To give up hope

B.Choice: To fill with fear

C.Choice: To feel exhausted

D.Choice: To lose direction

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Which statement logically predicts Yang Ki's next actions following her brother's rescue?

A.Choice: She will leave Nepal.

B.Choice: She will visit the Himalayas.

C.Choice: She will go to school.

D.Choice: She will train as a porter.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: In paragraph 10, the narrator mentions the Yeti to Yang Ki to

A.Choice: warn Yang Ki because he is worried about her.

B.Choice: urge Yang Ki to go home by frightening her.

C.Choice: distract Yang Ki by telling her an unusual story.

D.Choice: surprise Yang Ki by showing her the footprints.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence states a main idea of this article?

A.Choice: Some trees and other plants had special meanings to Native Americans.

B.Choice: Native Americans used the Cedar tree in many responsible ways.

C.Choice: Some Native Americans believed in preserving the natural resources of Earth.

D.Choice: Native Americans valued the Cedar tree for its beauty and long life.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which part of the tree did Native Americans use to make cooking vessels?

A.Choice: The bark

B.Choice: The branches

C.Choice: The slender roots

D.Choice: The steamed wood

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 7.
:box:Because of its life sustaining nature, the Native Americans revered the tree.
Which word means the same as r͟e͟v͟e͟r͟e͟d?

A.Choice: Replanted

B.Choice: Avoided

C.Choice: Shared

D.Choice: Cherished

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Based on paragraph 6, readers can conclude that the anchor lines for canoes

A.Choice: needed to be strong to secure the canoes.

B.Choice: were the smallest parts of the canoes.

C.Choice: needed to be waterproof.

D.Choice: were hard to use.

SubTopics: Analyze multiple accounts by various cultures of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.
Content: Which statement is the author's opinion?

A.Choice: “They believed in its power and spirit”

B.Choice: “The Red Cedar's wood is soft but firm and straight grained”

C.Choice: “The Native Americans' respect for nature is a good example for present generations to emulate”

D.Choice: “It was used as a trade item and given as a gift to high ranking women during the Potlatch ceremonies”

SubTopics: Analyze multiple accounts by various cultures of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.
Content: The author organized paragraphs 4–7 by

A.Choice: identifying the differences among the various parts of the Cedar tree.

B.Choice: explaining why objects made from the Cedar tree were beautiful and highly valued.

C.Choice: contrasting the ways Native American men and women used the Cedar tree.

D.Choice: explaining how Native Americans made objects from different parts of the Cedar tree.

SubTopics: Analyze multiple accounts by various cultures of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 4.
:box:For example, a seal-catching canoe was worth 15 blankets and was a symbol of great wealth.
The main purpose of this sentence is to

A.Choice: inform readers why Native Americans believed the Cedar had power.

B.Choice: emphasize how valuable a Cedar canoe was to Native Americans.

C.Choice: inform readers how much the making of a Cedar canoe cost Native Americans.

D.Choice: describe how Native Americans used the Cedar in many ways.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Who is the main speaker in the poem?

A.Choice: A child

B.Choice: The rain

C.Choice: A teacher

D.Choice: The wind

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: How does the poet organize the descriptions in lines 1–12?

A.Choice: He lists many of the objects found in a classroom.

B.Choice: He shows a windy day and then compares it to a rainy day.

C.Choice: He explains how the students behave in the classroom.

D.Choice: He begins with a sunny day and then shows changing weather.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Why do the teachers most likely stop teaching class in lines 15–17?

A.Choice: The teachers hear the students whispering.

B.Choice: The heavy rain makes it difficult to hear the teachers.

C.Choice: The darkened room makes it difficult to teach.

D.Choice: The teachers want the students to rest.

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: The poet uses repetition in lines 19–20 most likely to

A.Choice: establish a mysterious change in the weather.

B.Choice: emphasize the power of the storm.

C.Choice: create a peaceful mood in the classroom.

D.Choice: contrast the sound of whispering and rain.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: How do the children most likely feel in lines 29–33?

A.Choice: Excited about the rain

B.Choice: Content to go home

C.Choice: Eager to fall asleep

D.Choice: Tired of the rain

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Study the diagram.
problems/MNG5R/media/20a.jpg
According to lines 1–12, which sentence belongs in the empty circle?

A.Choice: Children run.

B.Choice: Teachers whisper.

C.Choice: Leaves shake.

D.Choice: Classrooms empty.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: The effect of the children singing to the rain is that the rain

A.Choice: stops.

B.Choice: ignores the request.

C.Choice: sleeps.

D.Choice: laughs at the request.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence is the best summary of lines 13–23?

A.Choice: Students and teachers enjoy a rest.

B.Choice: Students and teachers are tired at the end of the day.

C.Choice: Teachers remind students to speak quietly.

D.Choice: Students refuse to do their reading and writing.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which conclusion can readers make about the conversation in lines 29–41?

A.Choice: The rain has an important job to do.

B.Choice: The teachers want the rain to stop.

C.Choice: The rain will return to the school every day.

D.Choice: The parents are worried that the rain will continue.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: How does the speaker most likely feel in lines 42–43 of the poem?

A.Choice: The speaker is eager to play outdoors in the rain.

B.Choice: The speaker has accepted that the rain will continue.

C.Choice: The speaker is curious about what the rain has done.

D.Choice: The speaker has stopped listening to the sound of the rain.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which line from the poem gives the best hint about the main topic?

A.Choice: Line 2

B.Choice: Line 5

C.Choice: Line 6

D.Choice: Line 9

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Based on the story “Bread to Make,” the narrator at times turns her attention to the outdoors because she

A.Choice: enjoys the sight of snow.

B.Choice: hopes to see her father return home.

C.Choice: prefers to be somewhere other than school.

D.Choice: likes to watch her grandmother from a distance.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: In what time frame do the events in “Bread to Make” happen?

A.Choice: Weeks

B.Choice: Days

C.Choice: Months

D.Choice: Years

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 5.
:box:I sat at her feet, and light and fleeting as the touch of a butterfly, my hand touched her knee.
The narrator compares her hand to a butterfly to show that

A.Choice: she is not afraid.

B.Choice: her touch is gentle.

C.Choice: she is sitting near her grandmother.

D.Choice: her grandmother cannot feel her touch.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 6.
'Grandmother, have you ever seen the way trees seem to dance in a storm?' I began.
The narrator asks Grandmother this question most likely to

A.Choice: help her grandmother view storms in a different way.

B.Choice: learn about storms over farmland.

C.Choice: describe the landscape of the farm.

D.Choice: avoid loneliness by talking with her grandmother.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: In paragraph 20, the narrator's mother gives her a “proud smile” because the narrator

A.Choice: looks like her aunt.

B.Choice: has told a joke in Chinese.

C.Choice: repeats a term in Chinese.

D.Choice: has made dumplings for her aunt.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 22.
:box:My Aunt Shirley could have been the twin of my mother.
This sentence means that Aunt Shirley and the narrator's mother

A.Choice: look alike.

B.Choice: are acting the same.

C.Choice: are close in age.

D.Choice: stand side by side.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Based on her actions during dinner, the narrator's aunt most likely

A.Choice: is embarrassed by her poor English.

B.Choice: is happy to see her niece again.

C.Choice: thinks her niece looks like her sister.

D.Choice: wants to make her own Chinese dumplings.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 24.

:box:A wave of sadness passes over me, that I can't understand Chinese, that I've never earnestly tried to connect with my mother's culture, that I haven't seen this woman for so long; I know so little.
This sentence most clearly expresses that the narrator

A.Choice: feels unsure about her background.

B.Choice: dreads her aunt's departure.

C.Choice: regrets her lack of interest in her background.

D.Choice: detects her aunt's sorrow.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which is the most likely reason that family members prepare a specific menu for the aunt?

A.Choice: A person from another country may hesitate to eat American foods.

B.Choice: The narrator's mother wants to display her cooking skills.

C.Choice: A Chinese dinner always consists of at least six courses.

D.Choice: The narrator's parents want her aunt to feel at home.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why does the narrator consider the dumplings she has made “'bad ones'”?

A.Choice: They have been boiled too long.

B.Choice: They taste bad.

C.Choice: They have been dropped.

D.Choice: They are torn.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: The narrators in both stories are similar because they both

A.Choice: reach an important understanding.

B.Choice: struggle with another character.

C.Choice: reach the end of a journey.

D.Choice: solve a problem.
